body: @andrewor14 this seems to have legitimate failures...
The ordering of initialization in the DAGScheduler is very sensitive. Could this patch instead just move the Hadoop configuration up?
Wait, isn't it still a build timeout?

Latest master doesn't seem to propagate all the SPARK_\* env vars, so this bus is not present anymore.
Never mind, I am able to reproduce the infinite loop in the GraphX tests locally.
@pwendell Maybe we should merge this PR first for RC1 and then fix minor issues.

Great, so there's no easy way to set it based on profiles and support all Hadoop versions :). Maybe for Hadoop 2.3+ users, we can just tell them to add a new version of jets3t to their own project's build? We can certainly have our pre-built binaries include the right one too.
LGTM. @tmyklebu Thanks for fixing the partitioning in ALS!

It may be possible to prevent the display of the stack dumps in the "DAGSchedulerActorSupervisor closes the SparkContext when EventProcessActor crashes" test, but that's just cosmetic and can be done later.

We may also want to reorganize the DAGScheduler at some point to, e.g., move into the event actor some of the methods that are now `private[scheduler]` in the `DAGScheduler` class.  I know that @kayousterhout has some plans to refactor much of the DAGScheduler, so the reorganization that I am suggesting should probably wait until then.

Other than the few comments I just posted, this LGTM.

Can one of the admins verify this patch?

Right - the pattern is virtually identical except for an update function call. Can we abstract this away so that we can deliver the first 3 algorithms of ADMM with a few lines of code so that it's straightforward to add new versions of ADMM algorithms.

Hi, @mateiz @srowen , if Spark built with Hadoop 1.0.4/2.x (x < 3)  and jets3t 0.9.0 can access S3 smoothly, does it also mean that bumping to 0.9.0 is safe?

I'm going to give a manual test tonight or tomorrow
Sure, that would work. Please try it. Unfortunately I remember it having problems, but I could be wrong.

BTW one issue left here is that only one version of `RDD.intersection` currently takes an Ordering -- the compiler didn't allow having multiple versions of this method with default parameters, even though the default parameters were always only in the second parameter list. We could fix this by moving `intersection` to a new `PossiblyOrderedRDDFunctions` class with an implicit conversion there that grabs the ordering in just one place. It may also be possible to make the `numPartitions` and `Partitioner` parameters of a single method with a small API change.

Hey just a heads up - I've submitted a smaller one-line fix for the original issue as part of #488 - that's just because I want to pull it into a release candidate.

https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/488/files#diff-50e237ea17ce94c3ccfc44143518a5f7R378

In general this part of the code definitely could use some broader clean-up, so let's keep going with this patch...

The change to be logging would be good to remove, that's a widely used interface in Spark that's been stable for a long time, and it's been kept intentionally consistent with standard logger interfaces in case we want to change around the logging in spark.
